												The Hitman series of games was one I had always meant to get around to.  I owned three of the games for quite a while, but after picking up the last two (Contracts and Absolution) I finally decided to start playing through them.  Going into the first one, I fully expected it to be underwhelming.  It is old after all (released in 2000).  But even that didn't adequately prepare me for some of the infuriating old school design choices this game uses.First off, the game has occasional moments of brilliance.  The Hong Kong missions and the Budapest mission are shining examples of the potential of the Hitman premise.  But all the missions surrounding it are slogs to get through.  And it all comes down to one simple problem.Often, Hitman: Codename 47 doesn't seem to understand what the word "stealth" even means.Take, for example, the third jungle mission.  You're tasked with taking out a drug lord.  But he's holed up inside a mansion inside of a fenced compound crawling with guards.  There is literally no way to take him out silently.  The room he's in has only one entrance, and the moment you open the door he grabs a big machine gun and starts shooting up the place.  And if you leave any nearby guards alive, they will start shooting you immediately.  Sure, you have a couple respawns, but they don't do anything because the moment you get close to the guards that killed you they recognize you and sound the alarm once again.And it was in this mission that I finally realized how inconsistent the AI is.  Sometimes, they're incredibly stupid.  You can kill a guy on the other side of an open doorway from another guy, and that guy won't even notice.  However, sometimes you silently choke a guy who's in a completely different room (behind a closed door no less) from another guy, and the moment you walk through the door that guy somehow knows what you did and immediately starts shooting.  And there's no checkpoints so if everything hits the fan guess what?  You're starting that twenty minute long mission  all over again.This wouldn't be nearly as much of a problem if it wasn't for the randomness of it all.  The guard who psychically knows that I killed his friend?  A large portion of the time, it doesn't happen.  And there's no logic to it.  Sometimes he knows.  Sometimes he doesn't.  And this is endemic throughout the entire game.Then there's the mission design, and that's where the game will occasionally get incredibly lazy.  For example, one mission involves getting through a bunch of gates to get to a boat where your target is hiding out.  Unfortunately, no matter what disguise you are wearing (even if it's the same exact one as the guards protecting the gates), they won't let you through.  They yell at you when you get close, and if you try to pass, they start shooting.  It makes even less sense when you consider that EVERY OTHER GUARD CAN WALK THROUGH JUST FINE.I feel like a lot of the people still praising this game are feeling nostalgia because they played the game when it was new.  Considering that I haven't, maybe I'm just being overly critical because I'm more used to modern game design.  Whatever the case may be, I do  not  recommend this game, especially considering that I've heard Contracts remakes the best missions from this one (namely Hong Kong and Budapest).  I honestly would have skipped it if it wasn't for my masochistic completionist ways.I do plan on reviewing the rest of the franchise as well.  I'm interested to see how it evolves over time.

												Well, this series got off on a shaky start. If you are looking to get into the Hitman series and want to start at the beginning, you may or may not want to skip this one anyway. To start off, the graphics look great for the time, even though the draw distance is fairly low. Also, on more modern systems, you need to mess with the graphics options a bit so static textures don't behave like animated .gif files. Before even touching control configuration or resolution settings, make sure to set the renderer to OpenGL, no matter what. Otherwise, on a presentation level, Hitman does it's job.As for controls, they definitely take a bit of getting used to, and you'll definitely also have to mess with the controls for at least 20 minutes just to see what suits you. And some of the design choices for them, even for the time, don't make a whole lot of sense. Such as a dedicated sprint foreword key. Luckily, after at least five or so configuration changes, I managed.Regarding sound, the music does a pretty good job most of the time at setting the mood. Whether things are tense and you are sneaking up on your main target to slice their throat without making a peep, or running through a Columbian jungle running-and-gunning, Jasper Kyd did a solid job composing it.On a story level, the first Hitman is a bit basic, but still captivating enough to see through to the end. One thing that really spiced my interest is the references to movies such as Scarface or The Godfather.And finally gameplay, well, it's a lot of trial-and-error. On many missions you will find frustration as the game expects you to sit though hours and hours of you dying from the same problem when the solution was literally in the last place you would look. I really can't blame anyone for looking up a guide or walkthrough for the game, as it really doesn't give you a clue sometimes. And in regards to the missions, there are not a lot of them, so this trial-and-error frustration doesn't last too long. Some can range heavily in length and aggravation, and most aren't very replayable or memorable. There is a difference between a proper lack of hand-holding (i.e. something akin to Metroid) and tedious bull$hit.What also range between missions are the bugs. Yes, this 14 year old game that they are still selling on Steam still has bugs. None of them are necessarily game-breaking, but can ruin a would-be successful play through a mission. Some range from minor visual glitches, to enemies that spawn out of nowhere that somehow see through your disguise and murder you, to the game spontaneously crashing. In the end, for IO Interactive's first game, and it being the year 2000 when it was released, I give it a bit of leeway. And as a whole it isn't a bad game. I have to agree with the Metacritic score of 73/100 it was given. If you really want to start Hitman from the ground up and are willing to deal with a bit of annoying cr@p here and there, maybe wait for a sale unless you are really that eager.

 About Hitman: Codename 47 As the enigmatic Hitman, you must use stealth and tactical problem solving to enter, execute and exit your assignment with minimum attention and maximum effectiveness. For a price, you have access to the most devious devices, but how you use them will determine if you retire as a millionaire  Release Date: 23 Nov, 2000	 The Campaign 	One of the finest Stealth / Strategy RPG's of its generation, it puts you in the role of Agent 47, a shadowy assassin who is equally capable of slipping in and out of target locations un-noticed as he is of pulling out a pair of chrome-plated 'Ballers' and taking absolutely everyone out. With a broad range of missions from the 'Lee Hong Assassination' (Rooftop Sniper takedown) to the 'Massacre at the Cheung Chow Fish House' (No one comes out alive), the game provides a wealth of memorable situations you will talk about years down the road. Flaws	 The game is not without its flaws - for a game nearly 14 years old, gameplay mechanics can be somewhat clunky. Probably the biggest gripe however is the in-game Save option, which does not exist. If you are spotted in the middle of a mission or die, you will need to start the mission over. While not a big issue in the earlier (shorter) missions, this can become extremely frustrating on the later missions where you need to navigate a huge mansion with tons of guards and after 20 minutes of perfection, one mis-step means you're killed and need to restart.All in All  Hitman: Codename 47 is a very nice Retro Game!9/10 From Me Sweep

												At the time of this writing Hitman: Codename 47 is closing in on being 15 years old. Hitman: Codename 47 has a great concept. It is the first hitman game I have played and has the series' iconic game mechanic of changing clothes which I found to be very fun. Sadly, that was one of the only things fun about this game.The game maintains a level of enjoyment throughout except during longer missions where everything goes horrible every possible time for the player. This game is a stealth game but often times I came to realize that the game doesnt seem to understand what a stealth game should be. Often times Agent 47 is forced into shootouts or situations that cannot be stealthed through. This becomes frustating very fast as the game also has no checkpoints and Agent 47 is relatively fragile compared to most action heroes. This lack of checkpoints makes the game challenging but less fun. Mechanics sometimes further amplify this problem as controls are imprecise and patroling guards sometimes randomly know you are the mysterious man who killed someone 2 blocks away in that back alley that no one saw or heard anything from.  The game does feature a respawn mechanic which allows the player to come back to life at a preset area (usually where you completed your last objective) ; HOWEVER, it does not make you incognito and every guard that was shooting at you before will still be shooting at you now. The AI is terrible (Its understandable given the game is 15 years old)    Sometimes guards will be overly suspicious for no apparent reason. It is not unusual for a guard to hear a silent takedown and come running around the corner to see you over the body.. but because it was a silent takedown he obviously doesn't know it is you that performed the act. You can easily outsmart the AI but sometimes the game doesn't play by its own rules and someone downstairs three rooms away heard you when the guy right infront of you didn't. The rules / game mechanics are vague    Even now after beating the game and understanding the game a whole lot more than I did while playing it, I do not understand the rules of some AI or mission objectives. Often times the game throws you into a level with an absurdly vague objective and lets you wander to figure it out. Usually what you are supposed to do has very little to do with the information you were given or objectives are exponentialy more complicated than the brief mission objectives say. Mission objectives do not tell you if you have completed them or not leading to sometimes trying to leave a mission and not knowing why you cannot. Often times I have wandered into an area that gets me killed not knowing it was restricted access or worse guards only sometimes care which leads to situations where you play the exact same way twice with different results. The difficulty     Overall the game is challenging, but its a stealth game and getting caught is bad and gets you killed. Even ignoring the other flaws in the game the difficulty is still absurd. Missions can sometimes be really short and easy and then immediately you are thrown into a half hour minimum warzone with no idea what to do. Some missions I beat on my first try with no assistance from any walkthroughs and other missions even with walkthroughs it took me 5+ hours to beat a single mission. The first mission was almost impossible despite being incredibly straight forward. The first major assassination that takes place at a seaside restaurant is potentially the hardest. A later mission you are forced to take on a boss battle with Scarface Tony Montana who has an M60 while you have whatever little toy guns you can find lying around AND this is also in the middle of a larger mission where if you die you have to start all over due to no checkpoints. Final Thoughts    Overall the game isn't the worst experience of my life. Some missions in it may qualify for that title but the game overall is enjoyable. If you had checkpoints and could skip levels that were overly hard and long the game might actually be somewhat recommendable. I think the games age does play a part in why it was so hard but a little extra effort to explain details of what needed to be done would have gone a long way in making this game a much more enjoyable experience.

												Hitman: Codename  "I Need to Use the Bathroom" 47 is the first entry of the series and lays down the core mechanics for future Hitman games.It's not surprising that Codename 47 is the least played game of the entire series.Although it's not uncommon for people to completely skip the earlier games of a series in favor of a more updated and relevant experience, C47 is without a doubt a classic. However, like many underappreciated classics, you have to ignore some of the game's flaws in order to reach the best parts of the game.The controls are a bit strange at first, but after rebinding keys to something more intuitive, the only thing you have to get used to is pressing a separate button to run forward. The main flaws of C47 are the completely oblivious AI, the lack of an extensive rating system, and the sometimes linear level design. The enemy AI functions more like walking sentry guns than actual guards. No matter how many times you run up behind someone the AI never turns around and the moment you acquire a disguise you're free to run around restricted areas without any suspicion.Even if the stealth isn't rewarding, the fact that 47 isn't a bullet sponge will encourage a more strategical approach. The game shines because each level plays out like a puzzle. The reward of figuring out how to assassinate your target without any prior knowledge is unlike any other game.Some of C47's best levels include Traditions of the Trade and The Lee Hong Assassination because of the expansive, non-linear level design and multiple approaches to completing the objectives. The sheer replayability of these levels are what defines Hitman as a series.While Codename 47 is noticeably flawed, it provided the framework for future games of the series to refine. The AI is forgiving, but at the same time the levels will require multiple playthroughs in order to find the solution. The age of the game may put some people off, but if you're really interested in the Hitman series, Codename 47 isn't a bad game to start with. At least, it's definitely better than Absolution.

												Hitman Codename 47 puts you in the shoes of a born and bred assassin and sends you off after a variety of bad guy targets in a surprisingly open environment that lets you pick and choose how you will go about dispatching death this day.You start off waking in a hospital gown, in a cramped room somewhere out in the world, the only hints to your identity a bar-code stamped at the back of your head and a computer chip in your brain. You are then quickly taken through a series of training exercises and then given your first assignment. You never ask why, nor question who it is that sends you on these missions. You simply are a hitman, devoid of any ethical dilemmas or personal identity. As you progress through the story you will eventually begin to discover clues as to your origin but for now, there are people alive that shouldn't be.Each mission sets you into a open area with guards, civilians, cops and others roaming the place. Various events within the missions are timed, as your targets goes about their business and it's up to you to pick the time, place and method by which you dispatch them. Different missions provide different obstacles and while all the missions have a path of least resistance you will often find yourself experimenting with different plans.Which weapons and items you bring with you is chosen at the start of the mission at a fee although you can also pick up and use what you find throughout the mission as well as take the clothes of any unfortunate henchmen or passerby you happen to kill or incapacitate and although it requires some effort to get past the suspension of disbelief it requires when a 7ft. blad psycho with a bar-code tattoo on the back of his head passes for an oriental chef with only a change of shirts the mechanic works wonderfully in the game and the many disguises and the various places they allow you to go opens up many more avenues leading towards your target.In general the open-ended nature of the missions is what separates Hitman 47 from the pack. An early mission has you recreating the classic Sollozzo assassination from the Godfather movie. You can play along with the movie, stashing a gun in toilet, go to the meeting, excuse yourself and then come out shooting. You can also walk through the front door with your gun cocked taking out the targets henchmen first, or you can wait for the target to go to bathroom himself and shoot him through the window, or one of a myriad of other possibilities that the game gives you.The game looks stunning for it's time, with high quality graphics and textures. The maps are big but never devoid of life. Sound quality is acceptable but nothing out of the ordinary.It is not all roses however, the game hasn't aged well and what was great graphics back in the day is now all but unplayable to a modern audience. The lack of a proper save game function was not acceptable, even back then.All in all Hitman Codename 47 is a great experience, the open maps and the many paths to chose from makes this one of the few true assassination games. A definite buy for any fans of stealth and subterfuge.

An oldie but a goodie! That needs a cane and a hip replacement. Despite the big blue thumb above this text, I can only recommend this game to some. It's quite an old game (Older than myself), but old games can still be good, Doom being the prime example. But the thing is with Hitman: Codename 47, it REEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEALLY hasn't aged well, the controls are strange and archaic, but with some fiddling, you can get somewhat modern controls. (The run button is completely independent of the walk forward, so you hold it to run, without holding the W key, which is weird at the start.)Now, onto to pros and cons:Pros:Quite big open levels.A nice roster of weapons.A purchase screen at the start of some missions, which lets you take what you need for whatever your playstyle maybe be. (Though some missions don't give you this option, and instead carry over weapons from the previous mission.)The story tells you about 47 and the five men who donated DNA to create 47.There's a fair few ways to go about things, gun blazing (wouldn't recommend it) or all stealthily like.Some missions have RNG to spice things up, like the safes in The Lee Hong Assassination.Pretty sweet music!Its levels are all quite different visually, each hit (Which consists of a mission or possibly multiple.) takes place in a different place. One takes place in a Columbian forest looking for a lost relic, getting around a tiger and breaking into a camp to kill a Tony Montana wannabe. While another takes place in a Chinese restaurant/brothel in Hong Kong. Plus, unlike some games *cough cough* Hitman *cough cough*, the NPCs have accents. I can't really gage some of them, but to me, they mostly sound good. (Though the Budapest accents sounded a little strange)Cons:The graphics are pretty yucky, with pixel heavy textures.The controls. Ohhhhhhh, golly God, the controls! All hail rebindable keys.The AI is very... Unpredictable. Sometimes, you can do something, say stab a guy and get no indication anyone heard, no guns firing or any of that, but then you round the corner and somebody shouts something like "Alarm! Alarm! He's packing!" annnnd, your health bar magically empties. The end. Bye.Wacky resolutions from 16 years ago. So, if you're planning to record this, it's going to be shrunk in the corner doing its thing. (At least with OBS)Not the friendliest with it mechanics and such, I mean the tutorial is all right, and it serves a story purpose but besides that, ehhhhh.Not a very good entry point to the franchise, if you're new to the series, stay away unless you become a big fan who wants to see where their beloved series was born. (In a mechanically awkward, poorly textured house. Even for the time.)No checkpoint system. You die, back to the load out screen. Yeah, it's real annoying.So, in conclusion:/TL:DR;This, at least I'd say, is a good game. Good ideas, some levels really are quite nice (Such as the Thermal Bath hotel in Budapest, that's my favourite level.) but ultimately it's aged horribly and can be a chore to slog through at times, but overall it's a good game. If you get through the gunk, of graphics, controls and it's generally archaic nature, it can be pretty fun. But, if you're new, I hear Contracts remade some of the best levels from this game, so go check that out, or, if you do fancy getting this, you may as well pick up the Hitman Collection like I did! It includes all the Hitman games, pardoning the new, weirdly released one.

												Ahh yes, Hitman: Codename 47.It's a fun little game that involves Mr. 47 hitting men :)Waking up in a strange place that gives the protagonist an opportunity to escape that said strange place, we see 47 signing up for the ICA in the latest game and a year later back in the original game, we see Agent 47 hitting men in five locations including the mysterious Hong Kong, the corrupted Colombian jungle, the virtual representation of an actual hotel in Budapest, the ugly docks of Rotterdam, and that strange place that I already mention which is a Romanian hospital which is actually pretty strange.Here we see that the contracts that 47 received involves hitting men who are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s or 'soon-to-be-♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s' but what's interesting is that if you pay attention to your briefings (or read more of the lore) or read the letters that your dead targets left lying around, there's a sense of connection going on between your targets which leads to the horrid truth for 47 once he takes out his final target. Though nothing is really shown too explicitly that 47 realised the purpose of his existence, if you use your head and discover that the five targets are actually the five "fathers" of 47 since they donated their DNA for a project of creating an army of perfectly-skilled men.The revelation of being designed to kill haunts him, and so we never to get to see 47 again until two years later in Silent Assassin.I thought the gameplay still holds up somewhat well after 16 years since release.The controls is quite clunky though such as in order to run, you only need to hold one button and if you attempt to hold the 'Forward' button as well while running then 47 will walk instead.Something you need to get used to if you play games including the latest Hitman games that involves running by holding two keys that involves movement.At times, the 'Use/Action' key won't do anything on certain things and that can only be solved by right-clicking on the object which brings up the action menu.And the AI would be either too dumb or unfairly annoying (as demonstrated in mission 7, I mean Jesus, the AI is such a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥. There's no manual save/load system during missions so if you messed up then you have to restart your entire 10 minutes of progress all over again and even though there's a feature that would place you at a checkpoint once you die, the enemy AI will still be alerted of your presence so you'll have to gun your way to your objective if you really want to continue (and despite years of training, 47's aiming is awful as the bullets flies everywhere so I wouldn't exactly recommend 'Rambo' your way through this game at all).You should be able to play this game on any computer, even the weakest of this generation, but if you're unlucky then this game can be quite unstable including random crashes. In 3/4 of my playthrough, whenever I drop my items, they'll float in the air and some sound effects such as choking people with fibre wire went missing.And also the game sometimes freezes for me in a couple seconds whenever I talk to an NPC. 												The starter of my favorite game series right here. However, I played this one after finishing the other games in the series, and purchased this to see how it all started.First thing you'll notice, is that this game really shows its age. If the graphics don't turn you away (I really don't pay attention to graphics), at least the controls will be very painful to learn. Moving is stiff, picking things up is clumsy and the inventory system is the biggest hunk of♥♥♥♥♥♥I've ever seen in my years as a gamer. And yes the graphics are horrible nowadays. The draw distance is legit 20 meters, which is espesially annoying in missions like Say Hello To My Little Friend or Plutonium Runs Loose, which are mostly flat with very few obstacles, so the enemies see you before you can see them.After dealing with the obvious technical issues that you'll encounter right out of the gates, we'll go check out how the game actually plays. To make some comparison to the later games, here you can't sedate innocents, but you have to kill them whenever necessary. There's no lockpicking, and if there's a locked door, you have to find key for it. There's no rank system, and you are rewarded with money. This game really made me feel like an assassin and there's some really good, action film like atmosphere. Also the soundtrack is already as good as we are used to know in Hitman. I also like how clone-ish agent 47 is in this game. He moves, speaks and looks like a zombie, and shows no morale. He does whatever he's paid to or dies trying. This game is also very hard. But unlike Hitman 2, this is actually a fair game for the most part. See, here the AI isn't as overly paranoid as h2, and this game includes more puzzle solving than hiding from lunatic AI. In this game the disguise system is very close to the one in Blood Money If you are wearing right clothes in right place, and you don't do anything obviously criminal in public, guards will hardly notice you. As much as I love h2, I think that this type of AI suits Hitman better.And now to the actual missions, the core of the franchise. There are few highlights, that really are on the same levels as the other games, like Lee Hong Assassination and the original TotT (which is imo better than the remake), but other than that most levels are either very non-memorable of just very bad. Some levels feel very unfinished and thrown-in, to increase the game's lenght. Some levels have good ideas, but they fall flat for poor execution good example is the ending level where  47 goes to kill his creator and the other clones of him . It sounds so cool, but it's actually one of the worst levels in the game. A good example of a filler level is Jungle God: no targets, linear jungle track, that you can complete pretty much by holding "W" for couple of minutes. There's overall the feeling that the devs weren't quite sure what kind of game they wanted to make, since some of the missions seem so absurd. I still have to give credit for making each and every target memorable in some way. They just have somewhat more character, than most targets in the later games. From a pedophile-ish policeman to an egoistic drug lord, and from a suicidal terrorist (the one with Hawaii-shirt) to a mad cloner, everyone is somehow memorable, and all of them are total scumbags. This game makes you really hate your targets with passion. Also the changing atmosphere and music in each country is something really special.Afterall this game left a good taste in my mouth. Maybe it's because it's so damn hard and satisfying complete levels stealthily, but overall I enjoyed it a lot. I'd recommend this, but not for everyone. I don't really care about graphics in video games so that might be a problem for someone else. I'd also recommend to play some other Hitman games before this, because they are easier to get into, and better way to find out, are these kind of games your thing at all. Even though there weren't many good levels for me, I still enjoyed the atmosphere and the best missions hold up to this day.

												Hitman: Codename 47 is the first PC-exclusive installment in the series. Be warned this is not an easy game as it requires lots of patience combined with a hefty duration of trial & error. Also, the default controls doesn't do this game justice as they are horrible, I suggest you tweak the controls to your liking before playing. In addition you can't save the game so if you get killed or spotted you might aswell restart the mission by pressing Shift+Esc as the checkpoint system sucks and it will put everyone on high alert. Some missions can be long and tedious especially a level called  plutonium runs loose  iff you know what you are doing as most missions should take no more than 10-15 mins to complete. However, if you are willing to go for the ride you are rewarded with an amazing experiance. There is a feeling of satisfaction when completing a mission, taking out a guard and hiding his body then using his disguise to traverse the level undetected. The graphics are tollerable but there is alot of jaggies when you run this game in high resolution. This is easily fixed by applying AA in your graphics control panel, I personally applied 4xmsaa in the nvidia control panel and it worked like a charm.The steam version has some flaws, which are listed below with some fixes:When you first launch the game, you might get "Failed to find Steam" error. To fix this Verify integrity of game cache or Copy the steam.dll in the steam folder to the "Steam\SteamApps\common\hitman codename 47" directory. Now the game will launch.To fix some in-game crashes make sure to run the Hitman.exe in Windows XP (Service Pack 2) Compatibility Mode.To run the game in widescreen resolution, you need to edit the Hitman.ini file in the install directory. There is a problem with the steam overlay not displaying correctly and in my case it didn't appear at all. I wasn't able to fix this problem.Here are my recommended .ini tweaks:Include Setup\Locale.zip 
//DrawDll Render3DFX.dll 
DrawDll RenderOpenGL.dll
//DrawDll RenderOpenGL.dll 
SoundDll Sound.dll 
ScriptDll GSC.dll 
LocaleDLL Locale.dll 
Resolution 1920x1080
ColorDepth 32
Anisotropy 2 
AntiAlias
DisableLight
ShadowDetail 2
TextureResolution 0
DisableDXT
DisablePAL
Window
StartUpperPos 0,0
Note: In order to make the .ini tweaks to work do not run the configuration utility, do not change the graphics settings in-game. If you verified the game cache, the hitman.ini file will be restored to default, so make sure to back up your .ini file just in case. To sum up I recommened this game to old school stealth fans or to anyone who likes challenging games.

 If you can look for the gold beneath the rust, you're in for a treat. 7.3/10  Ah, the beginning of an era in the stealth/action game genre.  Hitman: Codename 47  is where the revolutionary  Hitman  series began in 2001. Being a fan since  Hitman: Blood Money , when I saw the series on sale, I was delighted, and am now in the process of playing through them. Gameplay: 7/10  The  Hitman  series' use of difficulty and required creativity have their beginnings here. You  WILL  have to pay attention to guards, their movements, what they react to, and their overall patterns. Some are quick, some are not. I'll admit, the gunplay in  Codename 47  is lacking, but not by a huge margin. You really do manage to get used to it after a while of practicing.  There are also additional bugs that may have to be worked around when encountered. The stealth mechanics, though, even for its age, are well kept. Dragging bodies, disguising, slitting throats; what's  not  to love?  Storyline: 9/10  This is where it all begins. Agent 47's long trail of bodies begins as he wakes up strapped to a bed, and explores more about his past and origins through the game. As far as an origin story goes, he's got quite a load here.  Graphics: 5/10  The graphics, mediocre even for the game's time, are nothing to guffaw at, even for nostalgia fans, and this particularly where the game falls short. Textures are dull and sometimes conflict with each other. Severely pixelated and blurry textures are not uncommon.Overall,  Hitman: Codename 47 , despite its age and its shortcomings, can be thoroughly enjoyed through the nice tint of some rose-colored glasses.

SummaryHitman; Codename 47 is a third-person stealth shooter and I/O Interactive's sleeper hit, which allows you to assassinate contract targets for cash and to unravel the past of the man known as Agent 47. Gameplay HItman Codename 47 plays smoothy allowing you to bind controls to stealthily drag enemies, holster weapons, talk to NPC's, drag away bodies from the sight of other enemies, assume their identity temporarily, use the environment to kill your foes, fire upon them with silenced (or unsilenced) firearms and amongst a huge list more. Hitman has unparalelled freedom in allowing you to take down your target as you want it, not how the game wants you to play.Plot Codename 640509-040147 is the designation given by the Prof. Dr. Otto Wolfgang Ort-Meyer a German scientist who worked on the genetics to create the world's best assassinator, with the recombinant DNA of 5 fathers all belonging to criminal overlords known as; Otto Wolfgang Ort-Meyer himself, Chinese restraunt owner Lee Hong, Columbian drug lord Pablo Belisario Ochoa, International terrorist Franz Fuchs and finally Arkadij Jegorov, a international gun launderer from Kazakhstan. Agent 47, his demeanour is cold, calculative and as sharp as a .338 Lapua Magnum round in your Cerebral Cortex, is set out to join the ICA, his base of operations that deliver him contracts to take up in assassinating his marks for money, however the marks set by his client may not be exactly say who he actually is.GameplayThe gameplay in Hitman Codename 47 places you in an open area with different places to execute killshots or strangulate your mark. Killing too many civilians will severely reduce your paygrade and the ability to purchase ammo and other equipment for the job and committing mass murder of innocents will inevitable cause you to fail the mission.GraphicsCodename 47 features detailed mipmapping, radiosity shadowing, high polygon counts and high resolution textures and use of physics ragdolls which were impressive for their time (near 2000). Though the repetition in the use of urban buildings is overused and the sprite/flat shaded sprites and textures for foilage are not very well done. The draw distance is terrible however due to time and the antiquity of the engine used. SoundThe games audio has high use of fidelity (16 bit, 48Khz was considerably high) in its soundtracks and is focused mainly on its theme which has a Jungle and Classical genre feel to it, sound effects are done to great effect, representing a solid bullet shot out of a Sniper Rifle into the flesh of someones face.

Hitman: Codename 47TL;DR - Skip this, buy the second gameI would like to start off by saying that, as of writing this review, I have played every Hitman game, with the exception of Contracts. This gives me the opportunity to compare the games with each other and how well they (still) hold up.Unfortunately, “Hitman: Codename 47” does not hold up very much. Time was not very kind to the game and it surely hasn’t aged all too well, making it rather difficult to recommend a playthrough. There are a number of issues that plaque Codename 47. Being made 2000, it sure looks and plays like a contemporary game of that era. The graphics are okay at best, but like many early 3D games, everything is kind of blocky, which might be the result of IO-Interactive being a very small developer with limited resources back in the day. The gameplay is just plain clunky and overly complicated for no apparent reason. Seriously, different buttons for normal walking speed and running, sidestepping (strafing) and turning around? It took a while and a lot of key rebinding to get used to these controls personally. Anyone who played other or modern FPS/TPS will likely have the same issue.Regarding the music, it’s good. Jesper Kyd, whom you may know as the composer for other games such as Assassin’s Creed, Borderlands and Kane & Lynch, is doing a fantastic job with very ambient, moody pieces, setting a perfect tone to a gritty game full of wetwork. The sound engineering in general is okay, nothing to complain about. However, the voice acting is atrocious. Thank god they casted people with their respective dialect to fit the correlating character, but none of them are any good. Especially Agent 47 himself sounds just really silly and it’s hard to take him serious. Then again, a lot of games had this problem and still have, so it’s hard to fault the game just on the VA alone. David Bateson, voice actor for 47, reprised his role in subsequent sequels, doing a lot better in those thankfully.Now, the biggest problem with “Codename 47” is simple: it just isn’t very good. What first appears to be a game about being sneaky and confronting targets with care and silence quickly just turns into a game that feels like a run-and-gun shooter, a pretty bad one. With the exception of two or three missions, the most part of the game is spent on gunning down the henchmen of your targets, before executing the targets themselves. Normally I don’t have a problem with blasting my way through waves of bad guys, however the problem here is A) we’re supposed to be a silent killer, so what gives? And B) the enemies have an unforgiving pin-point accuracy, leaving you dead before you can even insult the game for the cheap enemy fire.Things that are supposed to aid you in your quest are meaningless. Taking on disguises of dispatched enemies often times doesn’t work in your favor, simply raising an alarm for the AI, which, in this game means “Everyone knows who you are, even in disguise. Why? Because the game hates you”. The AI WILL see you, disguise or not, from across the map. They will follow you, find you and they will kill you, because apparently everyone absolved with a diploma from the Liam Neeson School Of Premeditated Murder. And did I mention some missions have a failstate? So when the alarm is raised, you’re pretty much out of luck and will have to restart the mission if you’re not quick enough to get to your target. Simply put, the AI is broken beyond belief and leaves a bitter taste on an otherwise promising game.Although I’ve been very critical about “Codename 47”, I want to address that I’ve had my fair share of fun with it. I loathed it more than enjoying it, but I would be lying if I didn’t enjoy some aspects, like the few missions which feel like actual Hitman games (the missions “The Lee Hong Assassination” and “Traditions of the Trade” come to mind).“Hitman: Codename 74” sets the foundations for a fantastic and still mostly unique video game franchises. The debut game is sadly overshadowed by subsequent games in every conceivable way. With the second game in the series, “Silent Assassin”, IO-Interactive out-done themselves already.If you would like to know how the franchise started, give it try. However, if you want to play a game that feels more like a proper Hitman, skip this one and just continue with the second game, Silent Assassin. Otherwise, try “Hitman: Contracts” which is basically an expanding and proper remake of the debut.

												The best of all Hitman series. There was a remake called "Contracts", but this is better.Itches a scratch no other game can. Especially after a long day at work.The interface is shunned by some people, but I find it better than in the rest of the series. You can aim precisely with your "eyes" standing still - this is what hitmen and bodyguards do under those sunglasses I presume. basically you can "unhook" your reticle from the character and move his aimpoint around. This is important because, like in real life, you aim with your mind first and then take out a weapon to shoot that target, this brings another level of immersion, especially knowing that your character is a cunning assassin who is meant to be as inconspicuous as possible until the last moment. There is also a more realistic representation of weapons in the game, for example you can pick up two different guns and use them akimbo-style, if you so wish, and have a beretta in one hand and a hardballer in the other.It is not easy to create a game with same game mechanics, but also suited for different playstyles. The mission diversity is just right. From creeping in the shadows of a hotel, to starting a Rambo-style war in the jungle. Some see this as a drawback, but I prefer variety in games, especially inventive stealth ones like this title, where you can pick from a myriad of approaches to eliminate your target.

												While it maybe a "Classic" in some eyes I don't have nostalgia for this one at all. If anything Im really starting to dislike it.So first things first. Nothing really works correctly. Its a stealth actiony game right? But stealth is bugged most the time. Try to sneak up behind a guy with fiber wire or a knife to silently kill him? He will turn around and shoot you in the face. The AI is like your mom in that they have eyes in the back of their heads. Thats a creepy thought....Also sometimes disguises will cease to work. Get into a shoot out and run off and put on a new outfit and some AI will still try and kill you on sight while others....just are okay with you. Its confusing and goes against later installments in the series. Some AI will instincively know it was you who killed some random guy so they will go out of their way to shoot you in the face. Its completely broken for me in the Lee Hong mission and thats where I stopped. So it feels more bugged in this way. Theres alot of other smaller things that just seem weird or broken like occasionally things get stuck floating that should have physics applied to. I suspect it would have been very easy to patch the AI in this so that the encounters like I mentioned don't happen in the ways they do but nope. This is just the old game.Lots and lots of trial and error. You need to go through missions by the book or you outright fail the mission. You might make it to the exfiltration point with all objectives finished only to find you attracted to much attention so you still fail anyway. Enjoy replaying that mission. You have the illusion of choice but in reality there is right and wrong ways to finish the missions. Atleast thats my experience up to the Lee Hong Assasination mission since I can't finish the same thing.Also, no save states? No saving at all inside a mission? Only a horrible respawn system that respawns you a set number of times upon death but the mission remains the same the moment you died? Its really the worst way I have ever seen for handling player death and checkpointing as its the easiest way design/programming wise but probably the most jarring and confusing gameplay wise.The games just not very good. I would suggest playing Blood Money if you just want to play a good Hitman game (don't touch Absolution as its absolutely garbage!) or any of the later games. I can look past the graphics and sound, but when the gameplay is meh....its just meh.

												This game-serie was recommended to me already a looong time ago, but never had the time to step into this hitman series. Recently there was a sale of hitman games on steam, so I decided to buy the first 4 games. And of course, I started with the oldest: Codename 47 from the year 2000. I read some reviews after finishing the game, but 1 thing I should have read before playing the game:Open Hitman.ini in the game's installation folder.Add these lines:Resolution 1920x1080WindowStartUpperPos 0,0I played the game in 800x600, because otherwise it didn't work. With these lines (i checked it), you could play full screen and the game looks better as well. I also changed the keys, because the standard keys are not playable for me.  I think Codename 47 is a good entry point for the series so that you learn who Agent 47 is and how he came to be. I am used to play games in 2000 as well (heck, already since 1987), so I am used to bad A.I. like in this game. Although sometimes situations in the game really don't make any sense. Read the story very carefully before a mission, because that is the only help you get and there is many times some hints and clues how to fninsh a mission.  + good music+ good atmosphere+ sometimes multiple ways to finish a level+ still worth to play- opponents shoot very accurate, once detected you can start over the level- no savegames- some levels are very dificult to finish without checking for some hints and tips- your second life/respawn is in many cases worthless since you are already discovered- figure things out on ur own by dying and dying and dyingOnce you know how to beat a level, it will take you next time between 5-15 minutes. Clearly there is one intended solution and it can contain a rather easy to miss element. These sorts of obstacles are not fun to figure out and on a few cases, led me to follow a walkthrough instead. And it crashes constantly right before some cut-scenes. Extremely infuriating if you haven’t reached so far into the level before. The story, mission layouts and soundtrack are all good though. I realise some of these issues are really down to the fact that this is a 17 year old game, but If I had known those things beforehand, I wouldn’t have had to waste 16hrs to find out. I think if you want to start the hitman series, then you needn’t worry about playing the first game.PS. No need to be alarmed by the negative review. 												First, Public service announcement: DONT USE Direct3D as a renderer, use OpenGL or you'll have trouble. Also follow the display guide on the guides section.Well, this is the game that actually got me into games. I remember my father playing it. I was like OH GOD STEALTHY, DAD WATCH OUT, DAD WHY DONT YOU CHANGE TO THOSE CLOTHES, DAD LOOK THE IDIOT LEFT A MASTER KEY ON THE DOOR. Good times. Now that I'm older I can notice the terrible voice acting LOL. The worst actor is actually 47, and that makes me laugh a lot. But well. YES I recommend this game. It's old? yes. You'll have some display problems that are quickly solvable? yes. Worth it? YES. There's even a fix for you to expand the default drawing distance. This was a time when the game didn't actually have any guide or reference for this particular way of tackling the "stealth" genre so not all the levels are pure stealth. You'll kind of hate the jungle levels, one in amsterdam and the final one (kind of a Boss fight) since they force you to reveal yourself and shoot and kill heavily armed, non final target NPCs. It took me hours (even now that I'm an experienced player) to pass the final jungle mission. Buy a freaking Kevlar jacket :D I have to say though, It's rewarding to place a good headshot.Other than those things, there are memorable missions: Lee Hong's, Frantz Fuchs', Boris' that, despite being featured in Hitman Contracts, they are played differently here. One warning though. The game's hardcore and unforgiving. Depending on the difficulty setting, you're given a number of lives. Resurrecting doesn't make the guards forget about you LOL. In the hardest setting you are given one extra live only in the hardest missions. Be patient and play well. Plan your assasinations, choose well your targets and weapons. "Wake up! Wake up my friend!" :DConclusion: This game is a classic, it has its flaws but its enjoyable. I'd recommend buying it on a sale. It's worth it. If you have a config problem just leave me a comment.
